Idempotent operations are good for various reasons - for instance to avoid =
multiple creation of the same resource in the face of network errors. But h=
ow is it actually done in practice? What are your "tricks of the trade"?

M=
ost implementations I have seen requires the client to create some kind of =
GUID and use that in a PUT operation. For instance in order to create a new=
 "person" resource:

  PUT /person/{person-guid} HTTP/1.1
  Content-Type: .=
..

  ... user data ...

If it fails then the client can retry the PUT oper=
ation to the same URL. The server must then keep track of succeeded "person=
-guids" (is there any "best practice" for how this is done?).

What other t=
ricks do we have? Did I even get the above pattern right :-)

Regards, J=F8=
